Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: SELECTIVE TRANSPORT IN BIOLOGICAL HYDROGELS - FROM DESIGN PRINCIPLES TO MECHANISMS
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hydrogels in Biology represent a class of molecular assemblies that are understudied, with many fascinating and important structure-function problems to discover and engineering applications to invent. Nuclear pores, for example, the tiny channels in the nuclear envelope, are filled with a hydrogel that controls the selective exchange of molecules between the nucleus and the cytoplasm. Another important biogel is mucus, made from highly hydrated biopolymers from a ombination of peptide and sugar subunits. Mucus coats all the wet surfaces in the human body, providing a selective barrier that allows nutrients and information in while keeping pathogens out. Hydrogels are an integral part of Biology and, yet, clear concepts of how they function are missing. The goal of this project is to elucidate the fundamental biophysical principles that allow biogels to act as selective barriers and filters, and the cellular mechanisms involved in building and regulating them. The project also will educate and engage community health leaders, teachers and students about the state-of-the-art science of hydrogels, emphasizing the importance of mucus barriers within the broader context of the Physics of nature's bio-materials. The research will also be the cornerstone for the development of free online teaching material, including a children's book and a video contest, enabling widespread public awareness and understanding of biological hydrogels.

The nuclear pore filter is an ideal system in which to elucidate general principles of biofiltration by hydrogels. Its molecular composition is well characterized, and can also be reconstituted from well-defined phenylalanine-rich repeat units. A unique suite of quantitativ methods and theoretical tools will be used to characterize selective transport and to elucidate the relationship between a particle's biochemical properties, and its mobility across nuclear pore hydrogel barriers. The project will also engineer hydrogel filters with a precise control of selected elements of the barrier, including the size, the charge, and the cross-link chemistry of the repeat units. The PI's aim is to substantially extend the already existing technology to study hydrogelbased filtering, and advance the field toward new frontiers, by addressing the function of repeat domains, the basic building blocks of many biological gels, in the regulation of barrier selectivity. Her goal is to provide the foundation for a theoretical framework that captures general principles governing selectivity in the nuclear pore, and likely also in other important biological hydrogels such as the mucus, and bacterial biofilms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological hydrogels are self-assembled systems made from highly hydrated biopolymers. They coat all the wet surfaces in the human body (and in other organisms), providing a selective barrier that allows nutrients and information in while keeping pathogens out. This NSF CAREER award has enabled my laboratory to unravel new fundamental biophysical principles that allow important biological gels such as found in nuclear pores, mucus, and the matrix surrounding microbes in biofilms, to act as selective barriers and filters. Specifically, this award has helped us elucidate detailed molecular properties that distinguish particles that permeate, or are rejected by, a defined hydrogel barrier. For example, we were able to show that commonly considered parameters such as net charge or lipophilicity are insufficient predictors for permeability; instead, the detailed spatial distribution of charged groups can strongly modulate diffusivity of a particle through the hydrogel.

This award has also enabled my laboratory to shed light on how selective gels can be created that filter particles based on their interactions. This is a major goal of nanotechnology, with far-reaching implications from drug delivery to controlling assembly pathways. However, selectivity is particularly difficult to engineer when the particles of interest are larger than the gel's characteristic mesh size; such particles cannot passively pass through the gel. This award has helped us identify that selective filtering may occur when the interacting particles transiently reorganize the gel's internal structure, enabling them to selectively 'dissolve' through the gel.

Our third achievement under this grant was to shed light on polymer-associated glycans. Glycans are an integral part of hydrogels in Nature, but their function outside of metabolism remains largely unexplored. This award has enabled us to discover how glycans from natural mucin biopolymers, the gel-forming building blocks of the mucus barrier, have strong regulatory potential over the differentiation, physiology, and virulence of microbial cells.

Intellectual merit: In addition to revealing specific design rules for manufacturing selective gels, our results have the potential to explain the origin of selective permeability in certain biological materials, including the nuclear pore complex, mucus, and the excracellular matrix. Our findings also shifted the paradigm view of mucus: it is not a simple catchall filter for particles but rather a sophisticated bioactive material with powerful abilities to manipulate microbial behavior. In addition, by introducing a well-defined in vitro system, we provided the field with tools that now enable a mechanistic analysis of microbe-mucus interactions.

Broader impact: The discoveries under this grant have provided ample opportunities for developing new educational content and extensive outreach efforts by my laboratory, enabling widespread public awareness and understanding of the importance of biological hydrogels. Our efforts under this grant have also allowed us to educate and engage community health leaders, teachers and students about the state-of-the-art science of hydrogels. For example, we have developed an annual hands-on workshop, 'Grossology', at the Boston Museum of Science; here we introduce the concepts of polymers and gels to elementary and middle-school children. Moreover, our work has lead to the development of the TEDEd educational video 'How mucus keeps you healthy'. Our work was also featured in two radio shows: NPR's Science Friday! Mucus'It's Snot What You Think and Big Picture Science A Twist of Slime. It also formed the basis of an educational video produced by STAT, Why mucus is the unsung hero of the human body, covering the basic functions of slime.
